articles.title: Australian economist argues China is conning the world on net zero
articles.summary: Leith Van Onselen is the chief economist at the MB Fund and MB Super and co-founder of MacroBusiness. He argues China is the biggest greenhouse gas emitter in the world. Australia and other countries are cutting back on fossil fuel use at the same time as China is expanding its manufacturing sector.

articles.title: Climate Whiplash and California Wildfires
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: Southern California wildfires have been blamed on climate change. Patrick Brown's analysis raises concerns about the connection between climate change and extreme weather events such as the Los Angeles fires. According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, weather reflects short-term conditions of the atmosphere while climate is the average daily weather for an extended period of time.

articles.title: Fire Restrictions Eased For Wairarapa's Southern Coast
articles.author: New Zealand Government
articles.summary: Fire and Emergency New Zealand has revoked the restrictions on lighting outdoor fires in Wairarapa's southern coastal area until further notice. The wetter, less windy conditions have slowed the rapid drying of vegetation. There haven't been any large fires so far this summer.

articles.title: Shangla bears brunt of climate change
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: Shangla district in the Hindukush Mountain range is experiencing the negative impacts of climate change. The lack of snowfall has been resulting in water shortage, causing natural springs and waterfalls to dry up. The level of water in streams is falling each year, affecting the electricity generation capacity of local hydropower plants. Deforestation and climate change are also affecting the local farmers.

articles.title: Humans brought the heat. Earth says we pay the price
articles.author: Rik Myslewski
articles.summary: Humans have been using fossil fuels for well over a century and are paying the price with increasing heatwaves and other extreme weather events due to climate change. Since 2010, 57 percent of the Earth's surface has seen all-time daily temperature records. The IPCC reports that human-induced greenhouse gas forcing is the main driver of the observed changes in hot and cold extremes.

articles.title: West Sacramento Invites Public Feedback on Draft Climate Action Plan
articles.author: Source
articles.summary: The draft of the Climate Action Plan for West Sacramento has been released. The plan outlines strategies to combat climate change and promote sustainability. It will be presented to the Environmental and Utilities Commission and the Planning Commission in the coming months, before it goes to the City Council for approval.

articles.title: Why Some Birds Fly South For The Winter
articles.author: Elias Nash
articles.summary: Birds are well-known migrators, their majestic flocks a delight to behold as they travel with the seasons. Their movements are the same year after year, following aerial routes known as flyways, while land birds and raptors typically fly inland. Most plants die in the winter cold, most insects disappear during winter, and some also migrate, most famously the monarch butterfly.

articles.title: World Bank: Belize Blue Cities and Beyond Project
articles.author: IEye News
articles.summary: The World Bank's Board of Executive Directors approved a new project to help Belize advance the blue economy based on the sustainable use of ocean and coastal resources for economic growth while protecting the environment and improving livelihoods. The $32.23 million initiative will focus on improving the management of coastal and marine resources, increasing safe water supply and reducing land-based pollution in targeted urban areas.

articles.title: Students to suffer at schools in climate firing line
articles.summary: Two-thirds of Australian schools are at high risk of climate change-related disasters. NSW and Queensland have the highest number of schools at risk, with 90 per cent of primary and secondary schools in the three highest-risk categories. Mandala Partner's Adam Triggs says this could further entrench gaps in education outcomes in disadvantaged schools.

articles.title: Fire-hit state struck by storms as heatwave continues
articles.author: Callum Godde
articles.summary: Millions of Victorians are in the grip of a three-day heatwave. Fire crews are trying to tame raging fires after a night of wild weather.   Â. Â  ily.  yy. y. y.

articles.title: Students to suffer at schools in climate firing line
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Two-thirds of Australian schools are at high risk of climate change-fuelled disasters. NSW and Queensland have the highest volume of schools significantly exposed to climate-driven weather events, upwards of 90%. Bushfire and hail pose the greatest climate risk nationwide. Students will swelter through 34 annual heatwave days by 2060.

articles.title: Students to suffer at schools in climate firing line
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Two-thirds of Australian schools are at high risk of climate perils such as floods, bushfires and storms that could set back students by disrupting their education, according to the UNICEF. The UNICEFA is concerned about the impact of climate change on education.

articles.title: The ENMOD Treaty and the Sanctioned Assault on Agriculture and Human and Environmental Health
articles.author: Marvin Herndon J
articles.summary: The ongoing covert sanctioned environmental modification activities constitute a de facto war on sovereign nations. Large-scale environmental modification cannot be construed as 'peaceful' and is fundamentally hostile. When the injection of airborne particulates into the troposphere stops, the last of the geoengineered particulates will fall to Earth and global warming will be reduced. Agricultural production and public health will improve worldwide.

articles.title: B.C. Climate News: Study says climate change made California wildfires more likely, more intense
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change says humans are the main drivers of climate change. It warns the window to limit warming to 1.5 C above pre-industrial times is closing. The Earth is now about 1.3 C warmer than it was in the 1800s. The past 10 years are the 10 warmest years on record.

articles.title: B.C. Climate News: Study says climate change made California wildfires more likely, more intense
articles.author: Tiffany Crawford
articles.summary: The Earth is 1.3 C warmer than it was in the 1800s. The past 10 years are the 10 warmest years on record. The world is not on track to meet the Paris Agreement target to keep global temperature from exceeding 1.5 C above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: American withdrawal threatens global climate efforts
articles.summary: The United States is one of the world's largest greenhouse gas (GHG) emitters. In 2023, its GHG emissions totalled 6,000 million tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalents. The European Union emitted 3,383 million tonnes and India 3,394 million tonnes. The financial sector experienced a seismic shift as leading US banks exited the Net Zero Banking Alliance.

articles.title: Stories from Locals Facing Climate Change Every Day
articles.author: B.Sc. Jessica Taylor
articles.summary: The people of Kiribati are living with rising sea levels and climate change. The Dayak people of Borneo's rainforests are threatened by deforestation and palm oil plantations. The Sundarbans Delta of Bangladesh witnesses nature's ferocity unfettered as villages disappear beneath unforgiving waters.

articles.title: Fire chiefs warn UK is not prepared for climate crisis impacts
articles.author: Robyn Vinter
articles.summary: The UK is not prepared for the impact of climate breakdown, fire chiefs have warned. They called on the government to take urgent action to protect communities. Met Office predicts that 2070 winters will be as much as 4.5C warmer and 30% wetter than they were in 1990, while summers may be up to 6C warm and 60% drier. The south of England is projected to experience temperatures reaching 40C and rainfall is expected to increase by a quarter.

articles.title: FMI: Finland warmed by 1.4C in first quarter of century
articles.author: Yle News
articles.summary: The first quarter of the 21st century was about 1.4 degrees Celsius warmer in Finland than the preceding period of 1975–1999. In 2000–24, monthly temperature records were broken in about half of all months. The summer of 2010 brought the highest temperature ever recorded in Finland, 37.2°C in Joensuu. Southern Finland had four consecutive winters with heavy snowfall in 2010–13. In the winter of 2019–20, southern Finland was completely snowless for almost the entire winter.

articles.title: Why 2025 Is The Best Year To Witness The Stunning Northern Lights
articles.author: Buzz Staff
articles.summary: The increased aurora activity is due to heightened solar activity, which is expected to peak in mid-2025. The Sun's 11-year cycle of activity is currently in its 25th cycle, which started in late 2019. According to astrophysicist Dr Renate Mauland-Hus, the solar maximum will bring an increase in aurora activities, with a peak anticipated for July 2025.

articles.title: Tidal waves ravage Salakope and Agavedzi as residents call for urgent intervention
articles.summary: Residents of Salakope, Agavedzi, and adjoining coastal communities in Ketu South Municipality of the Volta Region are reeling from the devastating impact of tidal waves that have swept through their towns. The latest disaster began on February 1 and is expected to continue until February 4. There are fears that the already fragile Keta-Havedzi-Denu-Aflao road network could be wiped away. The first phase of the Blekusu Sea Defence Project, which was completed a few years ago, provided some relief to communities along the stretch, but the second phase has not been implemented.

articles.title: ECOWAS Gives $770,143 Aid To Flood Affected Communities In Cabo Verde
articles.author: Daily Independent
articles.summary: ECOWAS has intensified its humanitarian efforts in Cabo Verde, providing a $770,143 aid package to help affected families rebuild their lives. A high-level technical mission led by Dr. Sintiki Tarfa-Ugbe, Director of Humanitarian and Social Affairs has been deployed.

articles.title: Global warming makes French reservoir a winter resort for migrating cranes
articles.author: Kenan AUGEARD
articles.summary: Lac du Der was created in the 1970s to stop flood waters heading down the River Seine towards the Paris region. Global warming has made the French reservoir an attractive winter retreat for migrating cranes. The number of cranes has increased tenfold in the past decade. Local farmers complain about the damage to their land caused by the migration.

articles.title: Global warming makes French reservoir a winter resort for migrating cranes
articles.author: Kenan AUGEARD
articles.summary: The Lac du Der used to be a popular destination for cranes flying from Scandinavia in search of the sun. Now it's an attractive winter retreat due to global warming and the rise in sea levels.      .   in global warming.

articles.title: Female Leaders in Climate Science and Sustainability
articles.author: B.Sc. Jessica Taylor
articles.summary: Dr. Katharine Hayhoe is the Chief Scientist at The Nature Conservancy in the USA. Greta Thunberg is a young Swedish climate activist. Dr. Vandana Shiva is recognized for her work in sustainable agriculture and Dr. Sunita Narain addresses the intersections of climate change and social issues. Dr Sylvia Earle's work is dedicated to ocean conservation.

articles.title: When Mega-Icebergs Melt
articles.author: Square1
articles.summary: Prof Geraint Tarling of the British Antarctic Survey is guest on Newsround with Shane Bergin and Ruth Freeman and Newsround's Newsround team.      .   "Newsround" is broadcast on newsround.com every day.

articles.title: Wintering waterfowl numbers down in North Dakota due to cold
articles.author: BISMARCK TRIBUNE STAFF
articles.summary: Biologists took part in the state Game and Fish Department's annual midwinter waterfowl survey in early January. About 88,000 Canada geese and 3,225 mallards were counted, which is down sharply from 300,000 geese in the survey last year. The cold temperatures in November and early January pushed many birds south and froze a considerable portion of the open water.

articles.title: Failed 'Crying Wolf' Predictions Have Reduced the Credibility of the Climate Cult to Well Below Net Zero
articles.author: Vijay Jayaraj
articles.summary: The era of climate alarmism may be waning, replaced by a more pragmatic approach to global challenges. The future of environmental policy likely is in practical, local solutions that balance mitigation of real pollutants with human prosperity. People increasingly recognize that access to abundant, reliable energy from fossil fuels and nuclear power is fundamental to human flourishing.

articles.title: CM stresses wetlands' role in climate protection
articles.author: Urdu Point
articles.summary: Maryam Nawaz Sharif has emphasized the critical role of wetlands in combating climate change, calling their protection essential for the environment's survival.  In Urdu Point and Pakistan Point News.    in Pakistani Point News, February 2nd, 2025.

articles.title: Cold spell continues as northwesterly winds and rising sea waves affect Oman
articles.author: Nisha Joshi
articles.summary: Saiq recorded the lowest temperature in Oman over the past 24 hours at 4.7°C. Other cold spots include al Mazyouna (5.7 °C), Thumrait (6.3°C) and Muscat (6°C). Northwesterly winds are set to intensify from Sunday evening and continue for several days. Winds are expected to cause rising sea waves along the coasts of Oman.

articles.title: Scientists sound the alarm after finding thousands of seabirds dead on beaches: 'The message is clear'
articles.author: Lindy Whitehouse
articles.summary: Marine heat waves are having a devastating impact on seabirds in Alaska. A heat wave between 2014 and 2016 killed between 50 to 75% of the seabird population. There has been no sign of the bird populations recovering in the years since. Warming waters are also impacting the behavior and migration patterns of some marine species.

articles.title: Fact-checker speaks out on 'hoax' theory trending on social media: 'We must continue to step up our efforts'
articles.author: Juliana Marino
articles.summary: AAP FactCheck debunked false claims circulating on social media disputing the climate crisis. A Facebook post wrongly claimed "global warming is a hoax." AAP FactCheck evaluated the study and explained the actual meaning of the research. Global temperatures are rising due to human-driven factors, including the use of dirty energy.

articles.title: Tanzania's environment body issues warning on heavy rains, landslides
articles.author: Media News Company
articles.summary: The National Environmental Management Council (NEMC) has raised concerns over the potential dangers posed by expected heavy rainfall and landslides. Forecasts predict above-normal rainfall in regions such as Shinyanga, Simiyu, Mara, Arusha, Kilimanjaro, and Manyara. NEMC is advising citizens to follow environmental regulations and avoid constructing buildings in high-risk areas.

articles.title: Officials sound the alarm as state's iconic monuments are put at risk: 'The impact is now'
articles.author: Juliana Marino
articles.summary: Rising sea levels are threatening Maine's iconic lighthouses. The Gulf of Maine is warming faster than 99% of the world's oceans. Maine Preservation is partnering with the American Lighthouse Foundation to help repair damaged lighthouse and protect them from future storms. Countries can help keep the planet cool by limiting the use of dirty energy and switching to clean sources of power.

articles.title: YOUR OPINION: Inconvenient truth
articles.summary: Al Gore predicted in 2006 that we must address the warming of the earth due to fossil fuel emissions within 10 years or face catastrophic weather events. Jenny Smith, Jefferson City, sends a letter to the editor about this to Al Gore and the global warming issue.

articles.title: 10 US cities where homeowners are safest from natural disasters
articles.summary: CoreLogic put together a list of the safest ZIP codes in the US based on property data, replacement costs, and natural hazard insights to determine how weather and climate disasters affect single-family homes financially. Los Angeles-Long Beach-Anaheim, California is one of the least-risk ZIP codes. Spokane-Spokane Valley, Washington has the lowest risk of climate damage.

articles.title: 10 US cities where homeowners are safest from natural disasters
articles.summary: Natural disasters are increasing and some people are reconsidering where they live in the US. CoreLogic put together a list of the safest ZIP codes based on the firm's Risk Score based on property data, replacement costs, and natural hazard insights to determine how weather and climate disasters affect single-family homes financially.

articles.title: How accurate are groundhogs in predicting an early spring? You're better off flipping a coin
articles.author: Erica Van Buren
articles.summary: Climate change is affecting the hibernation patterns of groundhogs. This year's Groundhog Day is on Sunday. Punxsutawney Phil's weather predictions are less accurate than a coin flip. The weather forecast for next week will be warmer than it has been for most of January.

articles.title: Lake Chad: Racing Towards Regional Stability, Development
articles.author: Leadership
articles.summary: The Lake Chad Basin (LCB) region has been plagued by violence, insecurity and human rights violations for decades. The most pressing challenge is the persistent threat posed by Boko Haram terrorists. Other factors contributing to the instability include climate change, poverty, underdevelopment and weak governance.

articles.title: Researchers study 'complex' sand dune changes
articles.author: Julia Gregory
articles.summary: Researchers at the University of Plymouth have been monitoring sand dunes along Cornwall's north and south coasts since 2007. They found some dunes are advancing faster than predicted, while others are retreating faster than expected. Climate change poses a significant threat to coastal dunes.

articles.title: Researchers study 'complex' sand dune changes in Cornwall
articles.author: Julia Gregory
articles.summary: Researchers at the University of Plymouth have been monitoring 31 sand dune sites along Cornwall's north and south coasts since 2007. They found some dunes are retreating faster than predicted, while others are advancing. Climate change poses a significant threat to coastal dunes, the report says.

articles.title: Soft spaces out, stick-fighting in: Dutch call for the return of risky play
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Jackie's popcorn caught on the fire. The party is worried about the Netherlands' sedentary lifestyle.   Â. Â   y. y. Y.  y,  y, in which the party is talking about playing with fire.

articles.title: Climate Crisis and Finance: Malawi's Urgent Battle for Economic Resilience
articles.author: Co E-EDP
articles.summary: Malawi's economy is threatened by climate change. The country has already suffered severe economic damage from persistent droughts, intense floods, and devastating storms. The latest disaster, Cyclone Freddy, resulted in over 1,400 deaths and the displacement of more than half a million people. The report highlights the vulnerabilities of Malawi's banking and insurance sectors to climate-related risks and outlines a policy roadmap to enhance financial resilience.

articles.title: 1 dead, thousands evacuated as Australia's northeast battles floods
articles.author: Ariana News
articles.summary: 2014 was the hottest year since records began, with average temperature 1.6 degrees Celsius higher than in 1850-1900. Every month in 2024 was the warmest or second-warmest for that month since the records began. Carbon dioxide concentration in the atmosphere reached 422 parts per million in 2024. U.S. experienced 24 climate and weather disasters in 2024 at a cost of $1 billion.

articles.title: Beyond production: Addressing the real challenges in Bangladesh's agriculture
articles.author: Shaikh Abdullah
articles.summary: Bangladesh's agricultural sector is facing multiple crises and challenges, according to a report by the task force on economic reforms. The report highlights that the productivity and growth rate of the agricultural sector are declining. About 45% of Bangladesh's workforce is employed in agriculture, but labour shortages are becoming more acute. The decline in paddy and jute cultivation due to labour shortages could pose a risk to food security. Bangladesh's agricultural exports stand at $2.5 billion, far behind Vietnam's $40 billion.

articles.title: Fire-ravaged state on high alert for 'killer' heatwave
articles.author: Callum Godde
articles.summary: A sweltering heatwave has breathed new life into bushfires. There are fears heat exhaustion could prove deadly among the community, as a result of the sweltering heatwave.   Â. Â   y. Y.

articles.title: Expert reveals biggest culture shock Brits have when moving country
articles.author: Alycia McNamara
articles.summary: Brits are shocked by Australian food, kangaroos and the mullet. A record number of Brits are moving to Australia for work-life balance and to enjoy a better work life balance. The 10 biggest culture shocks for Brits moving to Aussies are: Australian food and drinking culture, hot Christmas, coffee culture, local slang, sport popularity, swearing and barefoot in public.

articles.title: There's no time to be chill about climate change in Scotland
articles.author: Emma Armstrong
articles.summary: Since 1994, Scotland has lost 15% of its nature. Between 1964 and 2004, Scotland's rainfall increased by 20%. Scotland has more than 11,000 miles of coastline and many people work and live on those coasts. Remote Highland communities live in old housing stock, use oil or solid fuel for heating and gas for cooking and depend on infrastructure that's already patchy and unreliable.

articles.title: AP PHOTOS: Tens of thousands of migratory birds have made this Indian lake their winter home
articles.author: Ashwini Bhatia
articles.summary: Bar-headed geese gather at the Pong wetland in Nagrota Suriyan, Himachal Pradesh state, India, on Friday, Jan. 24, 2025. Black-headed gull hunts in a shallow pool at Pong Wetland, which hosts thousands of migratory birds in winter months.

articles.title: VIDEO: Teals target safe Labor seat in Fremantle
articles.summary: An independent is running on a climate change agenda. The Labor campaign insists cost of living is what's on people's minds in the current election campaign.      .   for the Labor Party. For the Independent Party, the issue is about climate change.

articles.title: Call for concerted efforts to tackle water shortage in Sindh
articles.summary: Sindh Climate Action Network (SCAN) has warned that the situation could lead to a humanitarian crisis for vulnerable communities already struggling with food insecurity. SCAN also criticized the newly elected U S government's decision to cut financial support for welfare organizations tackling malnutrition and climate change.

articles.title: The art of climate action: How creativity is reshaping fight against climate change
articles.author: Raymond Millagre Langa
articles.summary: Art is a powerful form of activism that can communicate complex issues in ways that resonate emotionally with people. Creative activism mobilises communities to engage with climate issues in meaningful ways. Artists must empower themselves with knowledge, sustainable practices, and strategic partnerships to be effective climate activists.

articles.title: Pattaya and Bangkok temperatures rising; monsoon affecting the Gulf of Thailand and the southern region weakening
articles.author: Pattaya Mail
articles.summary: Temperatures in upper Thailand will increase by 1-2°C due to a weakening high-pressure system. The northern and northeastern regions will continue to experience cool to cold weather. Central Thailand, including Bangkok and surrounding areas, the eastern region, and southern Thailand will experience cooler mornings. The mountainous areas will have cold to freezing conditions. The northeast monsoon affecting the Gulf of Thailand and the southern region is weakening.

articles.title: SEAVIEW's CHANGING LANDSCAPE
articles.author: Ali Ahmed Qureshi
articles.summary: Karachi's Seaview is an essential public space that has long served as a meeting ground for the city's diverse population. The Clifton Cantonment Board (CBC) has undertaken an ambitious landscaping project that has significantly altered the character of the area. The transformation of this public space is part of a larger wave of infrastructural changes, including the controversial reclamation of land for projects such as China Port.

articles.title: Letters: A dogmatic approach to fossil fuels is bad for the economy – and the environment
articles.author: The Daily Telegraph
articles.summary: "The global shift forcing Britain to change course on net zero" is the reason behind the change of course on the net zero policy.      .   "Global shift" is forcing the UK to change its policy on zero net zero.

articles.title: Why Sydney will keep its place as Australia's biggest city
articles.author: Matt Wade
articles.summary: In 2020, the Centre for Population predicted Greater Melbourne would overtake Greater Sydney as Australia's most populated city in 2026-27, but a review of overseas migration flows has changed that. The current population of Greater Sydney is 5.58 million, about 4 per cent more than Greater Melbourne's 5.36 million. The centre projects Greater Sydney's population to reach 6.47 million in 2034-35.

articles.title: WEATHER: How does the Earth's axis affect it?
articles.summary: Coeur d'Alene Press would like their weather writers to write an article on the Earth's axis tilt. It takes 10,000 years for the Earth to do its complete axis tilt and at present the Earth is at just past halfway through it. Earth's weather patterns are partly due to the axis tilt, sun's solar flares, moon moving away from the Earth and magma movements inside Earth's core.

articles.title: 2024 Marks Hottest Year Ever Recorded As January 2025 Nears Record Heat
articles.summary: Global temperatures have shattered records, with 2024 officially recognized as the hottest year on record. January 2025 is poised to be the warmest January ever recorded, averaging 1.75°C above pre-industrial levels. Since the establishment of the Paris Agreement, nations committed to limiting warming to within 1.5°C by the end of the century.

articles.title: OPINION: We can cut our carbon footprint with individual actions
articles.author: Albuquerque Journal
articles.summary: The effects of climate change are all around us. The only solution is to dramatically cut down on the use of fossil fuels. The federal government seems to be taking the reverse tactic and is ignoring the problem.    The Los Angeles fires started just before the fires started.

articles.title: UK Gardeners Urged To Put Grated Cheese In Their Gardens For This 1 Reason
articles.author: Huffington Post
articles.summary: This winter is no mild one. The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB) urges on their website: 'When it's really cold, birds need more energy to stay warm. In winter there's less daylight to find food and many of their usual sources run low'.

articles.title: Storm Éowyn: A precursor to the extreme climate risks that lie ahead
articles.author: RTE
articles.summary: The devastation inflicted by Storm Éowyn reminds us that we need to focus more on how to adapt to live with extreme weather events that are certain to get worse in the future. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has warned of the dangers of climate change.

articles.title: Rats are rising in the cities and it's because of global warming
articles.author: Haaretz
articles.summary: New paper demonstrates correlation between urban crowding, rising temperatures and growing numbers of rats, who don't like the cold. It also shows that urban population is increasing due to rising temperatures.   Â      in this way rats are also increasing.

articles.title: World's largest iceberg on crash course with remote island; wildlife in peril
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: The world's largest and oldest iceberg is on a crash course with a remote island. If it gets into shallow waters, it can run aground on the ocean bed. The iceberg has been drifting for more than 30 years. It's commonly known as a "megaberg"

articles.title: Why Sydney is seeing so many antisemitic attacks of late
articles.author: system
articles.summary: An extremism researcher says the protracted nature of the recent war has in part contributed to an "unprecedented" wave of antisemitic incidents in Australia. The researcher is based at the University of Melbourne.    i.e. the war in Iraq and Afghanistan.

articles.title: From Germany to Belgium, how climate change allows winemaking further north in Europe
articles.author: South China Morning Post
articles.summary: Thanks to global warming, white wine is produced in Belgium and northwest Germany, and champagne grapes grow in southern England due to the climate change.      Â  .   in the UK, champagne grapes are grown in the south.

articles.title: Global warming makes French reservoir a winter resort for migrating cranes
articles.author: Khaleejtimes
articles.summary: The Lac du Der is attractive winter retreat for cranes. Tens of thousands of birds spend Europe's coldest months around the 48 sq km expanse of the reservoir. The cranes used to fly from Scandinavia in search of the sun. Now the birds do not have to go so far.

articles.title: Kolkata among 9 cities at risk of getting flooded by 2100. Here's why
articles.author: Live Mint
articles.summary: Kolkata is among nine cities at risk of flooding by 2100 due to rising sea levels from climate change. Experts warn that global warming will increase extreme weather events, resulting in more frequent and intense floods in Kolkata and other cities.

articles.title: Trump effect
articles.author: Majid Burfat
articles.summary: Donald Trump's recent withdrawal from international climate commitments has shaken the fragile foundation of global climate action. The Paris Agreement symbolised the spirit of solidarity in limiting global warming to well below 2C. Trump's policies disproportionately affect vulnerable nations, including Pakistan, that rely on international support to mitigate and adapt to climate impacts. The global community must unite to counter such setbacks.
